'''Oscar''' is a [[therapy cat]] living in the Steere House Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in [[Providence, Rhode Island]], U.S. since 2005. He came to public attention in 2007 when he was featured in an article by geriatrician David Dosa in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]''. According to Dosa, Oscar appears able to predict the impending death of terminally ill patients by choosing to nap next to people a few hours before they die. Hypotheses for this ability include that Oscar is picking up on the lack of movement in such patients or that he can smell biochemicals released by dying cells.<ref>{{cite|last=Leonard|first=Tom|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/7129952/Cat-predicts-50-deaths-in-RI-nursing-home.html|title=Cat predicts 50 deaths in RI nursing home|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=February 1, 2010}}</ref>
Oscar was also the subject of Dosa's 2010 book, ''Making Rounds With Oscar: The Extraordinary Gift of an Ordinary Cat''.<ref name="apjan312010"/>
==Background== Oscar is a therapy cat that was one of six cats adopted in 2005 by the Steere House Nursing and Rehabilitation Center in Providence, Rhode Island, U.S. Steere House, which bills itself as a "pet friendly" facility that allows a variety of pets to visit and reside there, is a 41-bed unit that treats people with end-stage [[Alzheimer's disease|Alzheimer's]], [[Parkinson's disease]] and other illnesses, most of whom are generally unaware of their surroundings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.steerehouse.org/Activities/pets|title=Pet therapy|publisher=Steere House website|accessdate=March 20, 2009}}</ref> Oscar has been described as generally aloof and "not a cat that's friendly to people",<ref name=Fox>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290840,00.html|title=Oscar the Cat Predicts Nursing Home Deaths|newspaper=Fox News|date=July 26, 2007|accessdate=March 20, 2009|author=Associated Press|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081103101404/http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,290840,00.html|archive-date=2008-11-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> sometimes hissing at people when he wanted to be left alone.<ref name=NEJM/>
===Death prediction=== After Oscar had been at Steere House for around six months, staff noticed that Oscar often chose to nap next to residents who died within several hours of his arrival. It seemed to staff as if Oscar were trying to comfort and provide company to people as they died.<ref name=sixsense>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/07/25/health/webmd/main3097899.shtml|first=Kathleen|last=Doheny|title=Cat's 'Sixth Sense' Predicting Death?|newspaper=CBS News|date=July 25, 2007|accessdate=August 4, 2016}}</ref><ref name=NEJM>{{cite journal|pmid=17652647|title=A day in the life of Oscar the cat|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=357|issue=4|pages=328–9|last=Dosa|first=DM|year=2007|url=http://content.nejm.org/cgi/reprint/357/4/328.pdf|doi=10.1056/NEJMp078108}}</ref>
Joan Teno, a physician at Steere House, clarified that "it's not that the cat is consistently there first. But the cat always does manage to make an appearance, and it always seems to be in the last two hours."<ref>{{cite|first=Lester|last=Haines|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2007/07/26/nursing_home_cat/|title=Cat senses impending death|newspaper=The Register|date=July 26, 2007|accessdate=August 4, 2016}}</ref>
After Oscar accurately predicted 25 deaths, staff started calling family members of residents as soon as they discovered him sleeping next to someone in order to notify them and give them an opportunity to say goodbye before the impending death.<ref name=NEJM/> {{asof|January 2010}}, Oscar had accurately predicted approximately 50 patients' deaths.<ref name="apjan312010">{{cite news|pmc=3603749|title=Just-Released Book Profiles Feline Angel of Death|first=|date=January 31, 2010|language=|author1=Henry, Ray|author2=Associated Press|newspaper=}}{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>{{clarify|reason=How often does he do this with people who aren't dying? How often do people die when he is available but doesn't show up? In other words, what are the specificity and sensitivity (and discriminant validity)?|date=December 2016}}
Oscar made international headlines in 2007 after the ''New England Journal of Medicine'' published an article about him by Steere House geriatrician David Dosa.<ref>{{cite|title=An Angel With Whiskers: Interview with Dr. David Dosa, author of 'Making Rounds With Oscar: The Extraordinary Gift of an Ordinary Cat'|first=Carol|last=Kaufmann|work=AARP Bulletin|date=June 10, 2010|publisher=AARP|accessdate=August 4, 2016}}</ref>
===Possible explanations=== Teno and Dosa hypothesized that Oscar is responding to the smell of chemicals released when someone dies<ref name=sixsense/> or some other odor emitted during death.<ref name=Fox/>
''CBS News'' consulted several animal specialists who had various hypotheses, such as that Oscar may be smelling some chemical that's released just before death and his attendance in rooms with that odor may be a learned behavior or that he's picking up on the stillness and lack of movement in the room rather than a smell.<ref name=sixsense/>
Some have argued that Oscar does not have an ability to predict death, and that this is a case of [[confirmation bias]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=MacGregor |first1=Trish |last2=MacGregor |first2=Rob |title=Sensing the Future: How to Tap Into Your Intuition and Read Signs From the Universe to Predict What's to Come |publisher=Page Street Publishing |page=97}}</ref>
{{asof|2015}}, it is believed that Oscar has accurately predicted 100 deaths.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Raven|first1=David|title=Can Oscar the cat predict people's deaths?|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/miracle-cat-predicts-deaths-100-5365056|website=mirror|accessdate=21 May 2018|date=30 March 2015}}</ref>
==In popular culture== {{refimprove section|date=August 2016}} *In 2009, the 18th episode in the 5th season of the TV show ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'', "[[Here Kitty]]", involved a cat that had predicted numerous deaths by curling up next to dying victims' bedsides. *In 2010, a feature film was announced as being in development, based on Dosa's book.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118023122|title=Feline Oscar heads to big-screen|publisher=Variety.com|accessdate=2011-07-07|first=Pamela|last=McClintock|date=2010-08-20}}</ref> *In 2010, Oscar was featured in episode 104 of Discovery Channel's show ''[[Weird or What?]]''. *In 2013, [[Stephen King]]'s ''[[Doctor Sleep (novel)|Doctor Sleep]]'' sequel to ''[[The Shining (novel)|The Shining]]'', grown-up Dan Torrance is aided at a hospice by a prescient cat who can sense when people are about to die. King stated in an interview that Oscar served as an inspiration to the story.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://shelf-life.ew.com/2013/02/01/stephen-king-the-shining-doctor-sleep-preview |title=Stephen King unearths origin of 'The Shining' sequel 'Doctor Sleep' |publisher=EW.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130205064751/http://shelf-life.ew.com/2013/02/01/stephen-king-the-shining-doctor-sleep-preview/ |archivedate=2013-02-05 |df= }}</ref> *In 2014, the comedy film ''[[Just Before I Go]]'' features a cat seen curling up next to Greta's dying grandmother. *Seattle-based punk rock band [[Tacocat]] wrote a song about him entitled "Oscar". *In 2016, Season 27, Episode 13, "[[Love Is in the N2-O2-Ar-CO2-Ne-He-CH4]]", of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', Homer visits his father Abe at the Springfield Retirement Castle where the residents are afraid of "the cat that can tell if you're dying". A scene includes a retiree in a walker in front of the home dropping dead on the sidewalk when the cat walks in front of him and screeches. *In 2015, Oscar inspired a children's book, ''Oscar il gatto custode'', written by Chiara Valentina Segré and illustrated by Paolo Domeniconi, published by the Italian publisher Camelozampa. The book was then published by Ragged Bears in the UK and by Gibbs-Smith in North America, with the title ''Oscar the guardian cat''.
==See also== * [[Emotional support animal]] * [[Fred the Undercover Kitty]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Individual cats]] [[Category:Providence, Rhode Island]] [[Category:2005 animal births]] [[Category:Cats in the United States]] [[Category:Death predictions]]

{{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = | name = Paula J. Olsiewski | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = | image_size = | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = American | fields = biochemist | workplaces = Alfred P. Sloan Foundation | patrons = | education = | alma_mater = Yale College,
Massachusetts Institute of Technology | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = Dr. John Healy | partner = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Paula J. Olsiewski''' is an American biochemist. She is a Program Director at the [[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation]], where she created and directs the Foundation’s programs in the Microbiology of the Built Environment, the Chemistry of Indoor Environments and Civic Initiatives. She directed the Biosecurity program{{cite book|last1=Gronvall|first1=G.K.|title=Preparing for Bioterrorism: The Sloan Foundation’s Leadership in Biosecurity|date=2012|publisher=Center for Biosecurity of UPMC|url=http://www.upmchealthsecurity.org/our-work/publications/preparing-for-bioterrorism-the-sloan-foundations-leadership-in-biosecurity}}{{cite journal|last1=Hitchcock|first1=P.J.|last2=Mair|first2=M|last3=Inglesby|first3=TV|last4=Henderson|first4=DA|last5=O'Toole|first5=T|last6=Ahern-Seronde|first6=J|last7=Bahnfleth|first7=WP|last8=Brennan|first8=T|last9=Burroughs|first9=HE|last10=Davidson|first10=C|last11=Delp|first11=W|last12=Ensor|first12=DS|last13=Gomory|first13=R|last14=Olsiewski|first14=P|last15=Samet|first15=JM|last16=Smith|first16=WM|last17=Streifel|first17=AJ|last18=White|first18=RH|last19=Woods|first19=JE|title=Improving Performance of HVAC Systems to Reduce Exposure to Aerosolized Infectious Agents in Buildings; Recommendations to Reduce Risks Posed by Biological Attacks|journal=Biosecurity and Bioterrorism|date=2006|volume=4|issue=1|pages=41–54|pmid=16545023|doi=10.1089/bsp.2006.4.41}}{{cite journal|last1=Morse|first1=S.S.|last2=Garwin|first2=R.L.|last3=Olsiewski|first3=P.J.|title=Next Flu Pandemic: What to Do Until the Vaccine Arrives?|journal=Science|date=2006|volume=314|page=929|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/314/5801/929|doi=10.1126/science.1135823|pmid=17095681}} until its conclusion in 2011 and the Synthetic Biology program until its conclusion in 2014. ==Education== Olsiewski holds a bachelor's degree in chemistry from [[Yale College]], and a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in biological chemistry from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (1979) with a thesis on D-amino acid dehydrogenase evolution, supervised by [[Christopher T. Walsh]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} From 1980-1982 she was a Postdoctoral Fellow in the lab of William H. Beers at [[New York University]].{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} ==Biotech and biomedical commercial development== Olsiewski directed commercial development for in vitro diagnostic products at Enzo Biochem, (NYSE:ENZ), a biotechnology company focused on the manipulation and modification of nucleic acids to produce therapeutic and diagnostic products.http://www.sloan.org/about-the-foundation/staff-directory/show-staff/show/people/paula-j-olsiewski/ She directed the New York City Biotechnology Initiative, a state funded program to improve the region's ability to grow biotechnology companies by fostering relationships between industry and academia. She also established and directed the Technology Development Office at the [[Hospital for Special Surgery]].http://www.sloan.org/about-the-foundation/staff-directory/show-staff/show/people/paula-j-olsiewski/ ==Board and advisory committee roles == Olsiewski is a consultant to the [[National Counterproliferation Center]], Chair of the Board of Scientific Counselors Homeland Security Research Subcommittee at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, and on the Board of Directors at the [[Critical Path Institute]]. In 2001 she served on the Board of Advisors for the WMD Center’s Bio-Response Report Card.[[Paula J. Olsiewski#cite note-6|[6]]] From 2003-2009 she was a member of the MIT Corporation.{{Cite web|url=http://web.mit.edu/corporation/membership/pastmembers.html|title=The MIT Corporation, Corporational Membership, Historical|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 24, 2017}} She was the first alumna to serve as President of the MIT Alumni Association (2003-2004), and served on the Advisory Board of the MIT Initiative on Faculty Race and Diversity[[Paula J. Olsiewski#cite note-7|[7]]] (2008-2009). She was a member of the Committee on Advances in Technology and the Prevention of Their Application to Next Generation Biowarfare Threats, which produced the National Research Counsel Report “Globalization, Biosecurity, and the Future of Life Sciences”[[Paula J. Olsiewski#cite note-8|[8]]] (2006). From 2005-2012 she served on the advisory board for the [[National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism|National Consortium for the Study of Terrorism and Responses to Terrorism (START)]]. ==Selected writings & publications== * Haynie, Sharon L.; Hinkle, Amber S.; Jones, Nancy L.; Martin, Cheryl A.; Olsiewski, Paula J.; Roberts, Mary F. (2011). “Reflections on the Journey: Six Short Stories.” ''Chemistry Central Journal'', '''5''' (69): 1-12. [http://ccj.springeropen.com/articles/10.1186/1752-153X-5-69 doi''':''' 10.1186/1752-153X-5-69] Her most cited papers, according to Google Scholar:{{Cite web|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=%22PJ+Olsiewski%22&btnG=&as_sdt=1%2C33&as_sdtp=|title=Google Scholar: "PJ Olsiewski"|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=Aug 10, 2016}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Olsiewski | first1 = Paula J. | last2 = Kaczorowski | first2 = Gregory J. | last3 = Walsh | first3 = Christopher | last4 = Kaback | first4 = H. Ronald | year = 1981 | title = Reconstitution of Escherichia coli membrane vesicles with D-amino acid dehydrogenase | url = | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 20 | issue = 21| pages = 6272–6279 | doi=10.1021/bi00524a056}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Olsiewski | first1 = Paula J. | last2 = Kaczorowski | first2 = G. J. | last3 = Walsh | first3 = C. | year = 1980 | title = Purification and properties of D-amino acid dehydrogenase, an inducible membrane-bound iron-sulfur flavoenzyme from Escherichia coli B. | url = | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 255 | issue = 10| pages = 4487–4494 }} *{{cite journal | last1 = Olsiewski | first1 = Paula J. | last2 = Beers | first2 = William H. | year = 1983 | title = cAMP synthesis in the rat oocyte | url = | journal = Developmental Biology | volume = 100 | issue = 2| pages = 287–293 | doi=10.1016/0012-1606(83)90223-3}} *{{cite journal | last1 = Morse | first1 = Stephen S. | last2 = Garwin | first2 = Richard L. | last3 = Olsiewski | first3 = Paula J. | year = 2006 | title = Next flu pandemic: What to do until the vaccine arrives?. | url = | journal = Science | volume = 314 | issue = 5801| page = 929 | doi=10.1126/science.1135823 | pmid=17095681}} == Awards and honors == In 1995 Olsiewski won the MIT Henry B. Kane '24 Award, which is given in recognition of exception service and accomplishments in the area of fundraising.{{Cite web|url=https://alum.mit.edu/sites/default/files/IC_assets/volunteering/docs/Henry_Kane_Awardees.pdf|title=MIT ALUMNI ASSOCIATION HENRY B. KANE ’24 AWARD WINNERS|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 24, 2017}} In 2000, she received the MIT Bronze Beaver Alumni Award, which is given in recognition of distinguished service - it is the highest honor the Alumni Association bestows upon any of its members.{{Cite web|url=https://alum.mit.edu/sites/default/files/IC_assets/volunteering/docs/Bronze_Beaver_Awardees.pdf|title=MIT ALUMNI ASSOCIATION BRONZE BEAVER AWARD WINNERS|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 24, 2017}} Also in 2000, she received the Yale Class Distinguished Service Award, which is selected by the class leadership and bestwowed to recognize and thank classmates who have dedicated time, energy and enthusiasm to the Class.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aya.yale.edu/content/class-award-recipients-0|title=Yale Class Award Recipients|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 24, 2017}} In 2018 Olsiewski was elected as a AAAS Fellow in the Chemical Sciences division.{{Cite web|url=https://www.aaas.org/news/aaas-honors-accomplished-scientists-2018-elected-fellows|title=AAAS Honors Accomplished Scientists as 2018 Elected Fellows|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=November 28, 2018}} == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Olsiewski, Paula J.}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American biochemists]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Synthetic biologists]]

revision.text:
[[File:Radium (stock horse).jpg|thumb|250px|Radium (1918-1947)]] '''Radium''' was an outstanding [[Australia]]n bred [[campdrafting|campdrafter]] and very influential ancestor of [[Australian Stock Horse]]s. He was a bay stallion bred by Donald Beaton of Levedale, [[Gloucester, New South Wales]]. This son of the outstanding campdrafter, Cecil (1899, by Red Gauntlet from Meretha II) from Black Bess by Hukatere (1882) was foaled on 11 November 1918. Beaton took great care in the breeding of his horses requiring horses with ability and stamina, for which he culled heavily. Radium’s sire, Cecil was so successful that in 1913, his owner, Arch Simpson was asked to leave his champion campdrafter at home in order that other competitors had a chance to win the campdrafting event at Geary’s Flat Bushman’s Carnival.
Radium was broken in by Archie Grant and Billy Tout when he was a two-year-old, after which he had several trips to the Cooplacurripa area. He began to show his exceptional ability as a stock horse as he developed and matured. Donald Beaton often drove long distances to compete at bushman’s carnivals with Radium tied behind the buggy. Radium would then compete in the campdraft, often winning and if he was going well, round off his success with an exhibition of campdrafting without a bridle. <ref>Starr, Joan. ''The Horse that Calls Australia Home'', Equine Educational, 1996, {{ISBN|1-875381-20-1}}</ref>
In circa 1928, Radium was sold to Herb O’Neil, who, as a friend of Donald Beaton, had ridden the horse in competitions for Beaton when he had been unable to get away from his property. Herb O’Neill competed extensively with Radium, winning over a large area of the state. Just prior to the [[Second World War]] (WWII), Radium won a Championship Campdraft at [[Kempsey, New South Wales]] with the next ten placings going to Radium’s sons and daughters. Radium was also highly successful in led contests for the best type of Stock Horse. During WWII, at a Dungog Bushman’s Carnival over 20 horses were competing in the led stock horse class. In this event Radium received the first placing with the remaining four all being his sons.<ref>Gower, Peter. ''Australian Stock Horse - Stallion Pedigree Book, Vol. 1'', Stock Journal Publishers, Adelaide, 1974</ref>
Radium stood at stud on "Kunderang Station" (now part of [[Oxley Wild Rivers National Park]]) for much of his life and had at least thirteen of his sons appear in Australian Stock Horse pedigrees. Quite a few horses had a double cross or were [[Outcrossing|line-bred]] to this great foundation sire.<ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/parks/guyFawkesHorsesV2App4.pdf Guy Fawkes Horses] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110321021106/http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/resources/parks/guyFawkesHorsesV2App4.pdf |date=2011-03-21 }} Retrieved on 2009-8-1</ref>
His son, Chan was one of the smartest horses seen in a cattle camp and was a good sire. Another son, Dimray foaled in 1938 was a brilliant campdrafter and when retired to stud, he carried on the Radium tradition of producing top stock horses and campdrafters. It was as a sire that Dimray had a tremendous influence with his son Reality, his grandson Rivoli Ray and his great grandson, Cecil Bruce being Hall of Fame inductees.
Radium died on 12 November 1947, at 29 years of age, of a genital malignancy. This was the end of the life of a truly great horse, but he was also the foundation of a great line of horses.
==See also== {{commons|Australian Stock Horse}} * [[Campdrafting]] * [[Muster (livestock)]] * [[Stock horse]] * [[Stockman (Australia)]] * [[Waler horse]]

[[File:Rahel Hirsch (LOC ggbain.15297).jpg|thumb|300px|Rahel Hirsch circa 1914]] '''Rahel Hirsch''' (September 15, 1870 – October 6, 1953) was a German doctor and professor at the [[Charité]] medical school in Berlin. In 1913 she became the first woman in the [[Kingdom of Prussia]] to be appointed a professor in medicine.<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Fraulein Now Professor. Rachel Hirsch The First Woman Physician To Gain That Title |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F06E3DE103FE633A25755C1A9679D946296D6CF |quote=Unusual honors have been won by Hirsch, who is the first woman physician in Germany to acquire the coveted title of Professor. ... |work=[[New York Times]] |date=November 16, 1913 |accessdate=2010-07-19 }}</ref>
==Biography== Rahel Hirsch was born on 15 September 1870 in [[Frankfurt am Main]], one of eleven children of [[:de:Mendel Hirsch|Mendel Hirsch]] {{Language icon|de}} (1833–1900). Mendel Hirsch was the director of the girls' school of the Jewish religious community in Frankfurt am Main. Mendel's father, Rahel's paternal grandfather, was the eminent rabbi [[Samson Raphael Hirsch]].
From 1885 to 1889, Rahel Hirsch studied for her degree in education in [[Wiesbaden]]; she then worked until 1898 as a teacher. After her doctorate she became assistant to [[Friedrich Kraus]] at the [[Charité]].
Since she was Jewish, the takeover by the [[Nazi]]s meant she could no longer practice medicine. In October 1938 she moved to London, where one of her sisters lived. Since her degree was not recognized by the British, she worked as a [[laboratory]] assistant and later as a [[translator]].
She spent her last years plagued by depression, delusions and persecutory fears. She died in a [[mental hospital]] on the outskirts of [[London]] on 6 October 1953 aged 83.
==Legacy== She is remembered by a sculpture in a square at the Charité, and by the naming after her of a stretch of road in front of the new [[Berlin Hauptbahnhof]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.berlin.de/ba-mitte/bezirk/gedenken/rahel_hirsch.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-12-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130412063044/http://www.berlin.de/ba-mitte/bezirk/gedenken/rahel_hirsch.html |archivedate=2013-04-12 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.berlin.de/stadtplan/?ADR_ZIP=10557&ADR_STREET=Rahel-Hirsch-Stra%C3%9Fe%20&ADR_INFO=%3Ca%20href=%22http://www.berlin.de/ba-mitte%22%3EBezirksamt%20Mitte%3C/a%3E]</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Richard Colvin Cox | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Richard Calvin Cox.png | image_size = 200px | alt = Actual yearbook photo of Richard C. Cox that was used for his official missing person flyer in the public domain. | caption = Richard Colvin Cox in his West Point uniform. Circa 1947-1950 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1928|07|25}} | birth_place = Mansfield, Ohio | disappeared_date = {{disappeared date and age|1950|01|14|1928|07|25}} | disappeared_place = [[West Point, New York]] | disappeared_status = Declared dead, 1957 | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | alma_mater = [[United States Military Academy]] | religion = <!-- Religion should be supported with a citation from a reliable source --> | denomination = | spouse = | parents = | relatives = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | allegiance = {{Flag|United States}} | branch = {{army|United States}} | serviceyears = 1947–1950 | rank = Third-class cadet | unit = {{Plainlist| * [[United States Constabulary|Sixth Constabulary Regiment]] (1947) * United States Military Academy}} (1948–1950) | awards = }} }} '''Richard Colvin Cox''' (25 July 1928 – last seen 14 January 1950) was a second-year [[Officer Cadet|cadet]] who disappeared from the [[United States Military Academy]] at [[West Point, New York]].
In January 1950, he was visited by a young man whose first name may have been George, three times over the course of a week. On the third occasion, Richard Cox and "George" left the grounds of the academy and were never seen again. According to an eyewitness account from another cadet, the two men seemed to have known each other somewhere other than West Point. Cox is the only West Point cadet to have disappeared without a trace.
==Early life and military career== Richard Cox was born in [[Mansfield, Ohio]]. After graduating from a public high school there in 1946, he volunteered for service in the [[United States Army]]. He joined the [[United States Constabulary]], a United States Army [[Gendarmerie]] force raised to be a police-type occupation and security force in Allied-occupied Germany.
In May 1947, he began his assignment to the Sixth Constabulary Regiment, based at [[Coburg]] in the [[American occupation zone]] in Germany.<ref>Maihafer, p.42.</ref> and was in the [[Staff (military)#Intelligence / security / information operations (2)|S-2]] (intelligence) section of Headquarters Company. Later in 1947, Cox applied for and received his appointment to [[West Point]], arriving at the [[United States Military Academy Preparatory School]] (then located at [[Stewart International Airport|Stewart Field]] near the academy proper) in January 1948.
Cox entered West Point in May 1948 and did well there. Academically, he was ranked at about 100 out of a class of 550. He joined West Point's athletic team and competed in a national [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] competition only a month before his disappearance.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://usconstabulary.com/richard_cox.html |title= Richard Cox, United States Constabulary Coburg, Germany 1947 |date=April 19, 2007 |website=United States Constabulary |publisher=United States Constabulary Association}}</ref> Cox was engaged to be married; he and his fiancé, Betty Timmons, planned to marry after his graduation from West Point.<ref name="Life" />
==Disappearance== At 4:45 pm on Saturday, January 7, 1950, a man telephoned Cox's West Point classmate, Peter Hains. Hains was acting as [[Charge of Quarters]] in Cadet Company B-2 (part of the North Barracks) and answered incoming calls for company members. He later said the caller's "tone was rough and patronizing, almost insulting."<ref name=Maihafer-p23>Maihafer, p.23.</ref> After Hains told the man that Cox was not in his room, the man replied, ''"Well, look, when he comes in, tell him to come on down here to the hotel. ... Just tell him George called – he'll know who I am. We knew each other in Germany. I'm just up here for a little while, and tell him I'd like to get him a bite to eat."''<ref name="Life" /> Hains later stated he could not be completely certain the name given was "George", as he had answered many phone calls while on duty and that one had not seemed noteworthy at the time; Cox never referred to the man by name.<ref name="Life">{{Cite magazine |last=Brean |first=Herbert |last2=Conant |first2=Luther |date=14 April 1952 |title=The Mystery of the Missing Cadet |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9FUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA161&pg=PA147#v=onepage |magazine=Life |publisher=Time Inc. |publication-date=1952-03-14 |pages=149–161 |access-date=27 March 2017}}</ref>
At 5:30 pm, a man entered Grant Hall - an area where cadets could meet guests - and asked to see Cox. The cadet on duty telephoned Cox, to tell him he had a visitor. The cadet later described the visitor as slightly under {{convert|6|ft|m}} tall and weighing around {{convert|185|lb|kg}}. He was fair-haired, had a fair complexion and wore a belted trench-coat, but no hat. When Cox entered the Hall, he shook hands with the man; the cadet on duty later recalled he seemed glad to see him.<ref name="Life" /> Cox signed out in the Company B-2 Departure Book, indicating he would have dinner off-campus. However, Cox later admitted to his roommates they did not dine, but drank from a bottle of whiskey while sitting inside the man's parked car.<ref name=Maihafer-p23-6>Maihafer, p.23-6.</ref>
Cox returned to Cadet Company B-2, signed the Departure Book, took a shower, and slept off the effects of the alcohol. (His two roommates later revealed this.)<ref name=Maihafer-p23-6 /> As a prank, his roommates photographed him, slumped over his desk, asleep.<ref name="Life" /> At an indeterminate time that evening, Cox altered the military time he had written in the Departure Book, changing "1923" to "1823" to make it look as if he had attended the 6:30 p.m. cadet supper formation.<ref>Maihafer, p.90-1.</ref> In fact, he had skipped the formation. This detail was not discovered until two years later, when an agent of the [[U.S. Army Criminal Investigation Command]] had the Departure Book examined in a laboratory.<ref>Maihafer, p.90.</ref> If the alteration had been discovered when it was fresh in January 1950, Cox could have been charged with violating the [[Cadet Honor Code]] and likely expelled.
The next morning, before attending the Sunday chapel service, Cox mentioned his visitor to his roommates. The man, Cox said, was a former [[United States Army Rangers|US Army Ranger]] who had served in the same unit as him in Germany. Cox said the man liked to brag about killing Germans during the war and had boasted about cutting off their private parts afterward. Another story he told Cox was about having gotten a German girl pregnant, and then murdering her to prevent her from having the baby.<ref>Maihafer, p.26.</ref><ref name="Life" /> That afternoon, Cox signed out a second time to meet the man, returning at about 4.30 pm.<ref name="Life" /> The following six days were without incident. Cox mentioned his visitor once to his roommates. He remarked that he "hoped he wouldn't have to see the fellow again," giving them the impression he viewed the man with distaste.<ref name="Life" />
On Saturday, January 14, Cox watched a basketball game between the Army and [[Rutgers University]]. Afterwards, he was seen talking to a man thought to be "George," although the cadet who saw the two talking gave a description that differed greatly from the description given by the cadet who had seen the stranger in Grant Hall on January 7. According to the eyewitness description from January 14, George was "dark haired and rough looking." Cox returned to his room and mentioned to a roommate he was signing out to dine with his visitor again, although he appeared "not apprehensive, just sort of disgusted."<ref name="Life" /> The two men left the grounds of the academy and vanished without a trace.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sheehan|first=Jerry|title=Mystery Hides Man Who Went To Dinner|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BHgfAAAAIBAJ&pg=3503%2C278107|accessdate=17 January 2013|newspaper=The Pittsburgh Press|date=3 January 1960}}</ref><ref>{{cite episode|title=West Point|series=America's Book of Secrets|airdate=2012-03-17|station=H2 Network}}</ref>
==Official Investigation== Cox was supposed to return by 11 p.m. When he did not return, no alarm was raised because cadets occasionally returned late. His continued absence was reported to a superior officer at 2:30 a.m., but again no action was taken as cadets had been known to stay out all night despite the punishment this would incur. On Sunday morning, his roommates reported all they knew of the matter to their superior; the [[New York State Police]] and the [[United States Army Criminal Investigation Command|CID]] were informed. The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] also became involved in the investigation.<ref name="Life" />
Three days after Cox's disappearance, a public appeal for information was broadcast on nearby radio stations.<ref name= Oblivion>[http://brandypurdy.blogspot.com/2009/05/oblivion-mystery-of-west-point-cadet.html Oblivion: The Mystery of the West Point Cadet, Richard Cox], by Harry J. Maihefer.</ref> The grounds of West Point were intensively searched by helicopter and by troops on the ground.<ref name="Life" /> The [[Lusk Reservoir]] was dragged, the banks of the [[Hudson River]] were searched and a nearby pond was drained.<ref name="Life" /> The manhunt lasted two months but produced no significant leads. A search of Army records for a soldier who had served with Cox and matched the description of "George", only led to individuals who could not have been at West Point at the time of the disappearance.<ref name="Life" /> Cox's service in Germany was investigated and revealed nothing out of the ordinary. The theory that he had deliberately deserted from West Point was discounted, as he had left behind in his room $87 (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|87|1950}} when adjusted for inflation) and two suits of civilian clothes.<ref name="Life" />
On March 15, 1950, Richard Cox was listed as [[absent without leave]].<ref name="Life" /> He was [[declared death in absentia|declared legally dead]] in 1957.<ref name= Oblivion />
== The Jacobs investigation == Harry J. Maihafer's book ''Oblivion'' (1996) documents the investigation conducted by Marshall Jacobs of Cadet Cox, who "vanished without a trace" from West Point in January 1950.<ref name="Harry J. Maihafer 1996">{{cite book|title=Oblivion|date=1996|author=Harry J. Maihafer|publisher=Brassey's Inc|edition=1st | ISBN=1574880438 }}</ref> Jacobs, a retired history teacher, began his research on the Cox disappearance in 1985. The more involved he became the more intrigued Jacobs became with Cox and the prior inconclusive investigations. It was inconceivable to Jacobs that after 35 years this mystery had not been solved.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hiaasen|first=Carl|title=The Case of the Missing Cadet Tracking The Clues For 38 Years|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-02-28/news/26242967_1_cadet-west-point-fbi-files|accessdate=17 January 2013|newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=28 February 1988|authorlink=Carl Hiaasen}}</ref>
Jacobs thoroughly investigated the case, traveling all around the country following up on new leads and revisiting old leads. He interviewed Cox's family, friends, service pals, and classmates; [[CIA]], [[FBI]], and [[United States Army Criminal Investigation Command|CID]] agents; and West Point and Army officials. He researched West Point's archives and the files from the FBI, CIA, and CID investigations of Cox's disappearance, to which he gained access under the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]]. Jacobs conducted a comprehensive and thorough investigation that took him over eight years to complete. Among Jacobs' findings was that authorities had been remiss when they had discounted the theory that Richard Cox had disappeared deliberately.<ref name="Harry J. Maihafer 1996"/> Jacobs came to believe that the presence of 87 dollars in Cox's shared room did not rule out the strong possibility that his visitor had helped him start a new career and life.<ref name="Harry J. Maihafer 1996"/>
When he was ready to reveal his findings Jacobs, admittedly not a writer, contacted Maihafer with hopes they could collaborate on a book. They did and the Jacobs investigation is revealed in the book ''Oblivion.'' The book has a section with photos including the snapshot that Cox's roommates took of him on January 7, 1950 sleeping off the effects of the alcohol he had consumed in his visitor's parked car a very short time earlier.
==See also== * [[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]]
==Bibliography== * Maihafer, Harry J., (1999). ''Oblivion: The Mystery of West Point Cadet Richard Cox''. Washington, D.C.: Brassey's. {{ISBN|1-57488-224-4}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1499&dat=19530109&id=lAMkAAAAIBAJ&pg=6323,3247141|work=The Milwaukee Journal|date=Jan 9, 1953|title=What Happened to Vanished West Point Cadet?}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=9FUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA147#v=onepage&q&f=false "The Mystery of the Missing Cadet."]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9FUEAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PP1&pg=PA147#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Mystery of the Missing Cadet|last=|first=|date=April 14, 1952|website=Google Books|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ''LIFE Magazine''. April 14, 1952.

{{About|Incidence of sexual abuse among partners|another article on this topic|Marital rape|more about violence between intimate partners|Domestic violence}} {{update|date=May 2016}} {{Violence against women}} '''Sexual violence by intimate partners''' deals with the incidence by country of [[physical abuse]], forced sex, or [[marital rape]] within the context of domestic violence. ==Domestic violence and sexual abuse== Domestic [[sexual violence]], such as forced sex or marital rape, may follow or be part of physical abuse, but is not always the case. In [[Mexico]] and the [[United States]], studies estimate that 40–52% of women experiencing physical violence by an intimate partner have also been sexually coerced by that partner.Campbell JC, Soeken KL. Forced sex and intimate partner violence: effects on women’s risk and women’s health. Violence Against Women, 1999, 5:1017–1035.Granados Shiroma M.Salud reproductiva y violencia contra la mujer: un ana lisis desde la perspectiva de género. [Reproductive health and violence against women: an analysis from the gender perspective of Nuevo Leon, Asociación Mexicana de Población, Colegio de México, 1996. Sexual violence may occur without physical violence.Hakimi M et al. Silence for the sake of harmony: domestic violence and women’s health in central Java. Yogyakarta, Gadjah Mada University, 2001. In the Indian state of [[Uttar Pradesh]], in a representative sample of over 6000 men, 7% reported having sexually and physically abused their wives, 22% reported using sexual violence without physical violence and 17% reported that they had used physical violence alone.Martin SL et al. Sexual behaviour and reproductive health outcomes: associations with wife abuse in India. Journal of the American Medical Association, 1999, 282:1967–1972. ==Incidence by country== Studies indicate that sexual assault by an intimate partner is neither rare nor unique to any particular region of the world. For instance, 23% of women in North [[London]], [[England]], reported having been the victim of either an attempted or completed rape by a partner in their lifetime. Similar figures have been reported for [[Guadalajara, Jalisco|Guadalajara]], [[Mexico]] (23.0%), [[León, Nicaragua]], (21.7%), [[Lima]], [[Peru]] (22.5%), and for the [[Midlands Province]] in [[Zimbabwe]] (25.0%). The prevalence of women sexually assaulted by an intimate partner in their lifetime (including attempted assaults) has also been estimated in a few national surveys (for example, [[Canada]] 8.0%, [[England]], [[Wales]] and [[Scotland]] (combined) 14.2%, [[Finland]] 5.9%, [[Switzerland]] 11.6% and the [[United States]] 7.7%). The table below summarizes some available data on the prevalence of sexual coercion by intimate partners. {| align="center" border="1" ! colspan="7"| Percentage of adult women reporting sexual assaults by an intimate partner
