page.title: Status and conservation of the golden eagle

revision.text:
{{Golden eagle}} [[File:Aquila chrysaetos 3 (Martin Mecnarowski).jpg|thumb|In flight in Czech Republic]] At one time, the '''[[golden eagle]]''' lived in a great majority of temperate [[Europe]], North [[Asia]], [[North America]], North [[Africa]], and [[Japan]]. Although widespread and quite secure in some areas, in many parts of the range golden eagles have experienced sharp population declines and have even been extirpated from some areas. The total number of individual golden eagles from around the range is estimated to range somewhere between 170,000 and 250,000 while the estimated total number of breeding pairs ranges from 60,000 to 100,000.<ref name= Watson>{{cite book|author=Watson, Jeff |title=The Golden Eagle|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aj5MNvCkun0C|year=2010|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-4081-1420-9}}</ref><ref>Rich, T.D.; Beardmore, C.J.; Berlanga, H.; Blancher, P.J.; Bradstreet, M.S.W.; Butcher, G.S.; Demarest, D.W.; Dunn, E.H.; Hunter, W.C.; Inigo-Elias, E.E.; Martell, A.M.; Panjabi, A.O.; Pashley, D.N.; Rosenberg, K.V.; Rustay, C.M.; Wendt, J.S.; Will, T.C. (2004). ''Partners in flight: North American landbird conservation plan''. Cornell Lab of Ornithology, Ithaca, NY.</ref> Few other eagle species are as numerous, though some species like tawny eagle, wedge-tailed eagle and bald eagle have total estimated populations of a similar size to the golden eagle’s despite having distributions which are more restricted.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |first=Leslie |last=Brown |first2=Dean |last2=Amadon |title=Eagles, Hawks and Falcons of the World |publisher=Wellfleet |year=1986 |isbn=978-1555214722 }}</ref><ref name= Ferguson-Lees>{{cite book |last=Ferguson-Lees |first=James |last2=Christie |first2=David A. |title=Raptors of the World |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |year=2001 |isbn=0-618-12762-3 }}</ref> The world’s most populous eagle may be the [[African fish eagle]] (''Haliaeetus vocifer''), which has a stable total population estimated at 300,000 individuals and is found solely in [[Africa]].<ref name="Brown"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://globalraptors.org/grin/SpeciesResults.asp?specID=8275 |title=''Haliaeetus vocifer'' |publisher=The Peregrine Fund |accessdate=2013-05-24}}</ref> On a global scale, the golden eagle is not considered threatened by the [[IUCN]].<ref name=IUCN>{{IUCN|id=22696060 |title=''Aquila chrysaetos'' |assessor=BirdLife International |assessor-link=BirdLife International |version=2013.2 |year=2013 |accessdate=26 November 2013}}</ref>
== Eurasia == In Europe, there are an estimated 6,000 to 10,000 breeding pairs. There was a great decline in [[Central Europe]] where they are now essentially restricted to the [[Apennine mountains|Apennine]], [[Alps]], and [[Carpathian Mountains]]. The strongholds in the continent are [[Spain]], which holds an estimated 1,300 breeding pairs, [[Norway]], which holds an estimated 860 to 1,040 breeding pairs and [[European Russia]], which holds an estimated 500 to 1,000 breeding pairs.<ref name= Birdlife>BirdLife International. (2004). ''Birds in Europe: Population estimates, trends and conservational status''. Birdlife International (Bird Conservation Series 12), Cambridge.</ref> Other European countries with stable and sizable populations include [[Italy]], with an estimated 476–541 pairs, [[Switzerland]], with 300–310 pairs and [[Romania]], with an estimated 85–130 pairs.<ref name= Birdlife/> The following nations are thought to have golden eagle populations that are increasing: [[Bulgaria]] with 150–170 pairs, [[Denmark]] with 1 known breeding pair, [[Finland]] with an estimated 300–350 pairs, [[France]] with approximately 390–460 pairs, [[Hungary]] with 3–5 known pairs, [[Ireland]] with 2 current pairs and [[Poland]] with approximately 35–40 pairs.<ref name= Birdlife/><ref>Nankinov, D., A. Dutsov, B. Nikolov, B. Borisov, G. Stoyanov, G. Gradev, D. Georgiev, D. Popov, D. Domuschiev, D. Kirov, E. Tilova, I. Nikolov, I. Ivanov, K. Dilchev, K. Popov, N. Karaivanov, N. Todoov, P. Shurulinkov, R. Stanchev, R. Aleksov, R. Tsonev, S. Dalakchieva, S. Ivanov, S. Marin, S. Stajkov, S. Nikolov, and H. Nikolov. (2004). ''Breeding totals of the ornithofauna Bulgaria''. Green Balkans, Plovdiv, Bulgaria.</ref> The following nations are thought to have decreasing golden eagle populations: [[Albania]] with about 50–200 pair, [[Croatia]] with approximately 90–110 pairs, [[England]] with no known current pairs, [[Greece]] with an estimated 100–200 breeding pairs and [[Latvia]] with somewhere around 5–10 pairs.<ref name= Birdlife/><ref name= Handrinos>Handrinos, G., & Akriotis, T. (1997). ''The birds of Greece''. Christopher Helm Ltd., A & C Black, London.</ref><ref>Radovic, D., J. Kralj, V. Tutis, and D. Cikovic. 2003. ''Red Data Book of birds of Croatia''. Ministarstvo zastite okolisa i prostornog uredenja, Zagreb, Croatia.</ref> Several other European countries have a small number of golden eagles with less than 50 breeding pairs but with populations that are generally considered stable.<ref name= Birdlife/> Despite their large population there, the golden eagle was considered near threatened in Spain in a 2003 report.<ref>Arroyo, B. & Del Moral, J.C. (2003). "Águila Real, Aquila chrysaetos", pp. 188–189 in Martí R, Del Moral JC eds, ''Atlas de las Aves Reproductoras de España. Dirección General de Conservación de la Naturaleza-Sociedad Española de Ornitología'', Madrid.</ref> One of the authors of the previous study asserted that the population had increased in 2008 by perhaps 20% in Spain since the last survey in the late 1990s.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Del Moral |author2=J. C. |year=2009|title=The Golden Eagle: breeding population in 2008 and census method|journal= Seguimiento de Aves |volume=32|pages=1–185}}</ref> In [[Belarus]], the population has reportedly declined considerably due to trapping, poisoning and the draining and development of upland bogs.<ref name= Ivanovski>Ivanovski, V.V. (1990). ''Breeding ecology of the Golden Eagle (Aquila chrysaetos) in northern Belarus''. Soobshcheniya Pribaltiiskoi Komissii po Izucheniyu Migratsii Ptits Akademiya Nauk Estonskoi SSR 22:130–154.</ref> The golden eagle is considered Critically Endangered in the [[Czech Republic]], where it was once quite common in the [[Beskids|Beskydy]] and [[Krkonoše|Krkonoše Mountains]] until logging hit the area hard around the time of World War II. All recent breeding attempts by the species in the Czech Republic are believed to have been unsuccessful.<ref>{{cite book |author=Kren, J. |title=Birds of the Czech Republic |publisher=Christopher Helm |year=2000 |isbn=0713647841 }}</ref>
In Britain, the last comprehensive survey of golden eagles took place in 2003, and found 442 occupied territories.<ref name="MH_1">Mark Holling and the Rare Breeding Birds Panel [http://www.rbbp.org.uk/downloads/rbbp-report-2003-04.pdf Report for 2003-4] accessed 4 March 2010.</ref> A less thorough survey in 2007 showed that in addition to large numbers of territories in the [[Scottish Highlands]] and the [[Inner Hebrides|Inner]] and [[Outer Hebrides]], there were a handful of birds in southern Scotland and northern England.<ref>{{cite journal |first=Mark |last=Holling |author2=Rare Breeding Birds Panel |year=2010 |title=Rare breeding birds in the United Kingdom in 2007 |journal=British Birds |volume=103 |pages=45–6 |url=http://www.rbbp.org.uk/downloads/rbbp-report-2007.pdf}}</ref> The population is higher today in Scotland than it was in the 19th century, due to the heavy persecution at that time by sheep farmers, gamekeepers, and collectors.<ref name= Watson/> There may have been as few as 190 pairs in the 1950s, though this survey may have not been complete.<ref>Nicholson 1957</ref> Between 1969 and 2003 they nested in the [[Lake District]], Cumbria.<ref name="MH_1"/> In [[Ireland]], where it had been extinct due to hunting since 1912, efforts are being made to re-introduce the species. In April 2007, a pair of golden eagles produced the first chick to be hatched in the Republic of Ireland in nearly a century. Forty-six birds were released into the wild in [[Glenveagh National Park]], [[County Donegal]], from 2001 to 2006, with at least three known female fatalities since then. It is intended to release a total of sixty birds, to ensure a viable population. The reintroduced golden eagles at the park produced a pair of fledglings for the first time in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.glenveaghnationalpark.ie/LatestNews.html |title=Latest News |publisher=National Parks & Wildlife Service |accessdate=2013-05-21}}</ref> The golden eagle is classified as bird of “High Conservation Concern” in Ireland.<ref>BirdWatch Ireland 2008</ref>
Fewer estimates are known from Asia and North Africa. A stronghold population is in mountainous [[Turkey]], where the large population included an estimated 2,000–3,000 breeding pairs persist. In [[Japan]], there is an estimated 175–260 breeding pairs, with a total population of approximately 500 individuals. One study stated that food shortages and decreases in suitable foraging habitat are assumed to be responsible for an observed decline in population size and reproductive success in Japan.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ozawa, T.|year= 2008|title=The population of Golden Eagles (''Aquila chrysaetos'') in Toyama Prefecture and their critical condition|journal= Aquila Chrysaetos |volume=22|pages=1–9}}</ref> In the Koreas, the golden eagle is known to be rarely observed and, in 2010, only 10 were seen in [[South Korea]] during winter birding censuses. Little is known in terms of population numbers elsewhere in Eurasia, with the IUCN estimating between 100 and 10,000 individuals each in China and in Russia, numbers that suggest the species occurs very sparsely in these massive countries.<ref>Brazil, M. (2009). ''Birds of East Asia: eastern China, Taiwan, Korea, Japan, eastern Russia''. Christopher Helm, London.</ref> In North Africa, the main occurrence is in [[Morocco]], which is estimated to hold 200 to 500 breeding pairs. There appear to much fewer in other North African countries, with small, scattered populations in [[Algeria]], [[Tunisia]] and [[Egypt]], areas where no immature-plumaged eagles were observed in 2005.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Thiollay, J.-M. |title=The decline of raptors in West Africa: long-term assessment and the role of protected areas |journal=Ibis |volume=148 |issue= 2|pages=240–254 |year=2006 |doi=10.1111/j.1474-919X.2006.00531.x }}</ref>
== North America == In [[North America]] the situation is not as dramatic. One estimate of the number of breeding pairs in the contiguous Western United States that excluded [[California]], [[South Dakota]], [[Montana]] and [[Oregon]] was 9,387.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fws.gov/mountain-prairie/species/birds/golden_eagle/Final_Golden_Eagle_Report_8_30_04.pdf |title=Population Level Survey of Golden Eagles (Aquila chrysaetos) in the Western United States |format=PDF |author=Good, R.E. |author2=Nielsen, R.M. |author3=Sawyer, H.H. |author4=Macdonald, L.L. |last-author-amp=yes |publisher=U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service |accessdate=2013-05-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140505181136/http://www.fws.gov/mountain-prairie/species/birds/golden_eagle/Final_Golden_Eagle_Report_8_30_04.pdf |archivedate=May 5, 2014 }}</ref> The state with the largest known winter count of golden eagles is [[Montana]] with 13,138, followed by [[Wyoming]] with 10,072, [[Colorado]] with 7,081 and [[Utah]] with 5,993. [[Wyoming]] had the highest estimated set of breeding pairs 3,381–4,174, followed by 1,800 in Utah, 1,200 in Nevada and California and Idaho both with around 500 pairs (notably, Montana was not included in these particular studies, although the breeding population must include well over a thousand pair there).<ref>Harlow, D.L. & Bloom, P.H. (1989). "Buteos and the Golden Eagles", pp. 102–110 in ''Proceedings of the Western Raptor Management Symposium and Workship'' (Ed. B.G. Pendleton), Scientific and Technical Series No. 12. National Wildlife Federation, Washington.</ref><ref>Good, R.E. & Nielson, R.M., Sawyer, H.H., & McDonald, L.L. (2004). "Population level survey of Golden Eagles (''Aquila chrysaetos'') in the Western United States". Reported prepared for United States Fish & Wildlife Services by Western Ecosystems Technology, Inc. Wyoming.</ref> In 6 out of 8 Canadian provinces where golden eagles breed, over 10,000 birds were observed in breeding bird surveys.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.globalraptors.org/grin/SpeciesExtended.asp?specID=8162&catID=2007&childID=148&sSpeciesName=Aquila_chrysaetos |title=Aquila chrysaetos- Additional details on Conservation |publisher=The Peregrine Fund |accessdate=2013-05-03}}</ref> In 1981, it was estimated that there were 63,242 wintering individual golden eagles in the 16 Western United States (excluding Alaska).<ref name=ole>{{cite journal|author=Olendorff, R. R.|author2= Miller, A. D. |author3=Lehman, R. N. |year=1981|title=Suggested practices for raptor protection on power lines-the state of the art in 1981|journal= Raptor Research Report|volume= 4|pages= 1–111}}</ref> However, there has still been a noticeable decline in some areas.
== Threats ==
{{very long|section|date=May 2016}}
Almost all threats to golden eagles are attributable, directly or indirectly, to human activities.<ref>Franson, J. C., L. Sileo, and N. J. Thomas. (1995). "Causes of eagle deaths", p. 68 in ''Our living resources''. (LaRoe, E. T., G. S. Farris, C. E. Puckett, P. D. Doran, and M. J. Mac, Eds.) U.S. Department of the Interior, National Biological Services, Washington, D.C.</ref> Human-sourced threats include: habitat change, persecution, poisoning (often directed at other species) and collisions with man-made objects.<ref name= Watson/> The most widespread unintentional threat to golden eagles by humans is urbanization and human-population growth which have made areas historically used by eagles unsuitable both in terms of habitat and prey availability. [[Habitat destruction]] in North America had, by the late 19th century, already driven golden eagles from some regions they used to inhabit.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Henninger, W.F. |year=1906|title= A preliminary list of the birds of Seneca County, Ohio|journal=[[Wilson Bulletin]]|volume=18|issue=2|pages= 47–60|url=http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/wilson/v018n02/p0047-p0060.pdf}}</ref> In [[Southern California]] and the [[Colorado Front Range]], this has been proved via long-term population and habitat surveys.<ref>Scott, T. A. 1985. ''Human impacts on the Golden Eagle population of San Diego County''. Master's Thesis. San Diego State Univ. San Diego, CA.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Boeker, E. L.|year= 1974|title=Status of Golden Eagle surveys in the western states|journal=Wildlife Society Bulletin|volume=2|pages= 46–49|jstor=3781966}}</ref> In [[Western China]], the main threats to golden eagles are land development, the use of pesticides and captures for falconry.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ma, M. |title=Government-sponsored Falconry Practices, Rodenticides, and Land Development Jeopardize Golden Eagles (''Aquila chrysaetos'') in Western China |journal=Journal of Raptor Research |volume=47 |issue=1 |pages=76–79 |year=2013 |doi=10.3356/JRR-08-26.1 |last2=Ming |first2=Ma |last3=Feng |first3=Xu |last4=Ragyov |first4=Dimitar |last5=Shergalin |first5=Jevgeni |last6=Nai-Fa |first6=Liu |last7=Dixon |first7=Andrew }}</ref> Fires since 1980 have caused large-scale losses of shrubs and jackrabbit habitat in areas used by eagles throughout the [[Intermountain West]] of North America. Wildfires that burned more 40,000 hectares of scrublands between 1981 and 1987 in the [[Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area]] affected nesting populations adversely. Nesting success at burned territories in Snake River Canyon declined after major fires. Abandoned burned territories have been subsumed by neighboring pairs, resulting in a decreased number of nesting pairs.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kochert |first=M.N. |first2=K. |last2=Steenhof |first3=L.B. |last3=Carpenter |first4=J.M. |last4=Marzluff |title=Effects of fire on Golden Eagle territory occupancy and reproductive success |journal=Journal of Wildlife Management |volume=63 |issue=3 |pages=773–780 |year=1999 |jstor=3802790 |doi=10.2307/3802790}}</ref>
Where disturbance is regular, breeding failure for golden eagles is significantly more frequent. This was inferred in the 1982 Scottish breeding bird survey when disturbances were heavy in the Highlands.<ref name="Watson" /> Sheep farmers and egg-collectors are the leading cause of disturbances at the nests. Recreation, forest management and development projects such as road construction, mining or power generation are other potential sources of disturbances. When disturbed by humans at the nest, the parents frequently leave their nest for a period of up to two hours, reduced provisioning rates, endangered eggs or young to predation, as well as overheating, chilling or desiccation.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Sutler, G.W.|author2=Joness, J.L.|year=1981|title=Criteria for Golden Eagle, Ferruginous Hawk and Prairie Falcon nest site protection|url=https://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/jrr/v015n01/p00012-p00018.pdf|format=PDF|journal=Raptor Research|volume=15|issue=1|pages=12–18}}</ref> Human intrusion within {{convert|750|-|1500|m|abbr=on|ft}} of nests can cause a disturbance.<ref>Ruddock, M. & Whitfield, D.P. (2007). ''A review of disturbance distances in selected bird species''. Report from Natural Research (Projects), Ltd. To Scottish Natural Research, Banchary, UK.</ref> Nesting success was found to be reduced in Norway during years where the [[Easter|Easter holidays]] fell early, due to the volume of vacationers in the countryside in these years during the pivotal early stages of nesting.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Fremming, O.R.|year=1980|title=Kongeorn I Norge|journal=Viltmpport|volume=12|pages=1–63}}</ref> During a study in [[Wrangell – St. Elias National Park and Preserve]] of [[Alaska]], experimenters camped within {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}} of active nests, which led to reduced food delivery and nest attendance by the parents, then at {{convert|800|m|ft|abbr=on}}, at which distance the disturbance of nesting behavior seemed to decrease considerably.<ref>Steidl, R.J., Kozie, K.D., Dodge, G.J. Pehovski, T. & Hogan, E.R. (1993). ''Effects of human activity on breeding behavior of Golden Eagles in Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve; a preliminary assessment''. WRST Reserve Resource Management Report No.. 93-3. National Park Service, Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve, Cooper Canyon, Alaska.</ref> The topography of the landscape and location of the nest can affect how closely the nest can be approached without disturbance.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Camp, R.J.|author2=Sinton, D.T.|author3=Knight, R.L.|year=1997|title=Viewsheds: a complementary management approach to buffer zones|journal=Wildlife Society Bulletin|volume=25|pages=612–615|jstor=3783509}}</ref> Mining and various types of energy development occur in eagle nesting and wintering habitat. The practice of surface [[coal mining]] threatens the limited nesting sites in Wyoming.<ref>Phillips, R. L. & Beske, R.E. (1984). "Resolving conflicts between energy development and nesting Golden Eagles", pp. 214–219 in ''Issues and technology in the management of impacted western wildlife; proceedings of symposium'', Steamboat Springs, Colorado, November 15–17, 1982. (Comer, R. D., Merino, J. M., Monarch, J. W., Pustmueller, C., Stalmaster, M., Stoecker, R., Todd, J. & Wright, W. Eds.) Thorne Ecological Institute, Boulder, CO.</ref> In the Italian Apennines, high levels of nesting failures have been attributed directly to disturbance, due to increased tourism in remote mountain areas, construction of new roads and mining.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Allavena, J.|year=1985|title=Preliminary results on the Golden Eagle ''Aquila chrysaetos'' in the central-southern regions of the Apennines in Italy|journal=WWBGP Bulletin|volume=2|pages=79–81}}</ref> Aggressive behavior by golden eagles due to a human presence near the nest is considered exceptional and usually will only result in minor injuries if any, as a particularly bold eagle may rarely attempt to dissuade a human trespasser.<ref name="Gordon">Gordon, S. (1955). ''The Golden Eagle; king of birds''. 1st Am. ed. Citadel Press, New York.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Camenzind, F. J.|year=1969|title=Nesting ecology and behavior of the Golden Eagle ''Aquila chrysaetos'' L.|journal=Brigham Young University Science Bulletin, Biological Series|volume=10|pages=4–15}}</ref> Golden eagles are somewhat sensitive to human disturbance even while not nesting. Experimental studies showed that pedestrians, which caused flushing at {{convert|105|-|390|m|abbr=on|ft}}, were more likely to cause wintering golden eagles in Colorado to flush than vehicles, at {{convert|14|-|190|m|abbr=on|ft}}. This study showed that golden eagles were more sensitive to human disturbance during winter than several other raptor species, including bald eagles.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Holmes, T.L.|author2=Knight, R.L.|author3=Stegall, L.|author4=Craig, G.R.|year=1993|title=Responses of wintering grassland raptors to human disturbance|url=http://ulpeis.anl.gov/documents/dpeis/references/pdfs/Holmes_et_al_1993.pdf|journal=Wildlife Society Bulletin|volume=21|pages=461–468}}</ref>
The intentional killing of golden eagles has been a conservation hurdle for the species. Golden eagles are intentionally killed usually due to the fear of loss of livestock and game species. This is despite the findings of virtually every study of losses of stock to golden eagles has revealed that the actual amount of livestock killed by the eagles is negligible and financial restitution from conservation organizations should not be necessary, including those studies funded by the farming organizations or governmental programs seeking to justify the “control” of golden eagles.<ref name="Watson" /> While illegal in most countries today, hunting, trapping and poisoning may still occur. <ref>Phillips, R. L. (1986). "Current issues concerning the management of Golden Eagles in western U.S.A", pp. 149–156 in ''Birds of prey Bulletin no. 3''. (Chancellor, R. D. and B. U. Meyburg, Eds.) World Working Group on Birds of Prey and Owls, Berlin, Germany.</ref> In the United States, the golden eagle was given federally protected status in 1963. Occasionally, golden eagles may be caught in trap lines laid out to capture mammalian predators.<ref name="Bortolotti2">{{cite journal |author=Bortolotti, G.R. |title=Trap and poison mortality of Golden and Bald Eagles |journal=Journal of Wildlife Management |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=1173–9 |year=1984 |jstor=3801778 |doi=10.2307/3801778}}</ref> In a study conducted in Scotland, areas were broken down into low disturbance areas (with a low human presence and limited history of persecution), moderate areas (where minor disturbances occur, mainly unintentionally from hill-walkers or rarely intentionally by egg-collectors) or severe disturbance areas (where persecution, heavy disturbance and considerable egg-collecting is believed to still occur). In low disturbance areas, about 45% of nests failed, in moderate disturbance areas about 74% failed and in severe disturbance areas 93% of nesting attempts failed.<ref name="Dennis">{{cite journal|author=Watson, J. |author2= Dennis, R.H. |year=1992|title=Nesting site selection by Golden Eagles ''Aquila chrysaetos'' in Scotland|journal=British Birds|volume= 85|pages= 469–481}}</ref> 73 out of 147 inaccessible nesting sites in this study (50%) produced fledglings, whereas more accessible nests produced fledglings in only 21 out of 68 nests (31%).<ref name="Dennis" />
Poisoning, both intentional and unintentional, is also a threat. The usual targets of carrion-poisoning are species such as coyotes, red fox and gray wolves, which are considered pests that threaten livestock. However, golden eagles are occasionally targeted as well for the same reasons. The main cause of mortality for golden eagles in Britain has been poisoning, 51 eagles have been verified to be killed by poisoning from 1980 to 2008 but the actual number killed is probably higher.<ref name="Watson" /><ref name="Whitfield2">{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2003.09.003| title = The effects of persecution on age of breeding and territory occupation in golden eagles in Scotland| journal = Biological Conservation| volume = 118| issue = 2| pages = 249–259| year = 2004| last1 = Whitfield | first1 = D. }}</ref> A disproportionate amount of golden eagle poisonings in Scotland from 1981 to 2000 were linked to grouse moors (where grouse are kept for the pleasure of shooting) and were probably caused by gamekeepers deliberately poisoning eagles and foxes to keep their stock of grouse high.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0006-3207(03)00019-3| title = The association of grouse moor in Scotland with the illegal use of poisons to control predators| journal = Biological Conservation| volume = 114| issue = 2| pages = 157–163| year = 2003| last1 = Whitfield | first1 = D. P. | last2 = McLeod | first2 = D. R. A. | last3 = Watson | first3 = J. | last4 = Fielding | first4 = A. H. | last5 = Haworth | first5 = P. F. }}</ref> It is estimated that the adult survival rate is reduced by 3% to 5% in Scotland by intentional poisonings.<ref name="Whitfield2" /> In the 1980s, [[California ground squirrel]]s, considered agricultural pests, were poisoned by the anticoagulant [[rodenticide]], [[Chlorophacinone]]. In turn, the poisonings caused golden eagles, as one of the major natural predators of California ground squirrels, to die in turn.<ref>Peeters, H.J. (1994). "Suspected poisioning of Golden Eagles ''Aquila chrysaetos'' by chlorophacinone", pp. 775–776 in ''Raptor conservation today'' (Eds. Meyburg & Chancellor), WWGBP, London.</ref> At least 10 individuals died in 1971 from eating [[Thallium(I) sulfate]]–laced pronghorn set out by sheep ranchers in Wyoming; despite public outcries, poisoning by sheep ranchers continued into the 1980s.<ref name="Beans">Beans, B. E. 1996. ''Eagle's plume''. Scribner, New York.</ref> In the 20th century, [[organochloride]] and [[Heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]] poisonings were also commonplace, but these have declined due to tighter regulations on [[pollution]]. In southern Idaho, 10 out of 17 golden eagles examined were found to have had exposure to lead.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Craig, T.H.|author2= Connelly, J.W.|author3= Craig, E.H.|author4= Parker, T.L. |title=Lead concentrations in Golden and Bald Eagles |journal=Wilson Bulletin |volume=102 |issue=1 |pages=130–3 |year=1990 |format=PDF |url=https://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/wilson/v102n01/p0130-p0133.pdf}}</ref> Golden eagles did not prove as susceptible to poisoning from the pesticide DDT as other large raptors, probably because of their diet of mammals. Eggs from golden eagle nests that were collected after 1946 in North America had shell thicknesses similar to (less than a 10% difference) those collected in earlier years.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Anderson D. W. |author2=Hickey J. J. | year = 1972 | title = Eggshell changes in certain North American birds | url = | journal = Proceedings of the International Ornithological Congress | volume = 15 | issue = | pages = 514–540 }}</ref> However, in Scotland egg shell thickness did decrease by around 10% from 1951 to 1965.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ratcliffe, D.A. |title=Changes attributable to pesticides in egg-breakage frequency and eggshell thickness in some British birds |journal=Journal of Applied Ecology |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=67–107 |year=1970 |jstor=2401613 |doi=10.2307/2401613}}</ref> A dead golden eagle collected on the [[Isle of Lewis]] had the highest concentration of organochlorine known from a modern bird in Scotland.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Newton, I.|author2= Galbraith, E.A. |title=Organochlorines and mercury in the eggs of Golden Eagles ''Aquila chrysaetos'' from Scotland |journal=Ibis |volume=133 |issue=2 |pages=115–121 |year=1991 |doi=10.1111/j.1474-919X.1991.tb04821.x }}</ref> The higher effects of organochlorines in Scotland may be due to the fact that birds there consume a relatively high quantity of [[seabird]]s, as opposed to North America, where this practice is rare.<ref name="Watson" />
Death by collisions with man-made structures and objects can be a serious local issue. [[Electrocution]] or collision with [[power lines]] has become an increasingly significant cause of mortality since the early 20th century. Juveniles birds are more susceptible than adults, being generally less cautious and physically adept.<ref>Benson, P.C. (1981). ''Large raptor electrocution and power pole utilization: a study in six western states''. Ph.D. thesis. Brigham Young University, Prova, Utah.</ref> It is estimated that up to 70 golden eagles may be killed locally by wind turbines each year in west-central California, almost all of them being juveniles as opposed to adults which tend to remain on their home ranges that largely occur outside of the wind farm area.<ref name="Hunt">Hunt, W. G., Jackman, R.E. Brown, T. L., Gilardi, J. G., Driscoll, D. E. & Culp, L. 1995. ''A pilot Golden Eagle population study in the Altamont Pass Wind Resource Area, California''. Predatory Bird Research Group, University of California, Santa Cruz.</ref><ref>[http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/01/04/9952873-feds-propose-allowing-wind-farm-developer-to-kill-golden-eagles?lite Feds propose allowing wind-farm developer to kill golden eagles – U.S. News] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130104012634/http://usnews.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/01/04/9952873-feds-propose-allowing-wind-farm-developer-to-kill-golden-eagles?lite |date=2013-01-04 }}. Usnews.msnbc.msn.com (2012–01–04). Retrieved on 2012–08–22.</ref> Collisions with [[automobile]]s rarely claim golden eagle lives, though instances of this can increase in desolate areas during winter, when road-side prey or carrion may attract the eagles.
In a few cases, mankind has accidentally benefited golden eagles by logging previously heavily wooded areas. This has been recorded in the 1800s and 1900s in the [[Appalachian Mountains]] of the [[Eastern United States]], where [[reforestation]] has now made the habitat unsuitable for nesting eagles, and in [[Washington (state)|Washington state]], which still holds breeding eagles in desolate areas that have been logged.<ref name="Marr">{{cite journal|author1=Marr, N.V.|author2=Knight, R.L.|year=1983|title=Food Habits of Golden Eagles in Eastern Washington|journal=Murrelet|volume=64|issue=3|pages=73–77|doi=10.2307/3535265|jstor=3535265}}</ref><ref name="Spottford">{{cite journal|author=Spofford, W.R.|year=1971|title=The breeding status of the Golden Eagle in the Appalachians|journal=American Birds|volume=25|pages=3–7}}</ref> [[Afforestation]], the commercial planting of non-native woodland, is a serious issue in Scotland, with the largest amount of it occurring in southwestern [[Scotland]], especially in [[Argyll]]. During afforestation, the land is plowed and over 2,500 seedlings are planted per hectare, mainly with exotic conifers including [[Picea sitchensis|Sitka spruce]] (''Picea sitchensis'') and lodgepole pine (''Pinus contorta''). The woodland canopy closes and ground vegetation dies, making these dark and gloomy places until harvesting in 40 to 50 years. More than 50% of land in Scotland at an elevation of {{convert|200|-|600|m|abbr=on|ft}} has been planted as such. Afforestation requires removal of sheep and the fencing out or shooting deer, both important sources of carrion for golden eagles. Foraging areas of golden eagles have been confirmed to not include afforested areas.<ref name="Watson" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Marquiss|first1=M.|last2=Ratcliffe|first2=D. A.|last3=Roxburgh|first3=R.|year=1985|title=The numbers, breeding success and diet of golden eagles in southern Scotland in relation to changes in land use|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=34|issue=2|pages=121–140|doi=10.1016/0006-3207(85)90104-1}}</ref>
== Conservation == The golden eagle is not threatened at the species level but efforts need to be taken to prevent extinctions from many northern countries. The primary efforts undertaken to conserve the species have been, in order of prevalence from highest to lowest: conservation education and awareness, policy protection, directed land management, legislation and law enforcement and the provision of indentures.<ref name= Watson/> In Scotland, only 3 out of 16 regions in Scotland occupied by golden eagles since 1982 have been deemed favorable for conservation status, based upon the extent of local persecution, prey abundance and habitat change.<ref name="Whitfield">Whitfield, D.P., Fielding, A.H., McLeod, D.R.A. & Haworth, P.F. (2008). ''A conservation framework for the golden eagle: implications for conservation and management in Scotland''. Scottish Natural Heritage Commissioned Report No. 193. Scottish Natural Heritage, Battleby.</ref> The United Kingdom has put in place deterrent legislation to prevent behavior around the nest with the potential to cause harm and acts of willful harm to white-tailed eagles and some have advocated using the same policies for golden eagles.<ref name= Whitfield/> Education in this region mainly is undertaken by the Royal Society for Protection of Birds (RSPB). To curb the destructive practice of afforestation, some locals have switched to planting native [[Caledonian forest|Caledonian pine forests]] instead, likely resulting in much less harm to the native fauna possibly including golden eagles.<ref>McGrady, M.J., Petty, S.J., & McLeod, D.R.A. (2004). ''Potential impact of new native forests on golden eagles in Scotland''. Scottish Natural Heritage Commissioned Report No. 18. Scottish Natural Heritage, Edinburgh.</ref> While conservation efforts in Scotland have previously included the setting aside [[Site of Special Scientific Interest|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs), these are usually too small to benefit golden eagles. More recently, the United Kingdom government has instead taken from governmental policies enacted in [[Continental Europe]] the idea of [[Special Protection Area]]s (SPAs), which offers strong legal protection of single species. Potentially more than {{convert|7000|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} may be set aside in Scotland as SPA for golden eagles.<ref>Stroud, D.A., Chambers, A., Cook, S., Buxton, N., Fraser, B., Clement, P., Lewis, P., McLean, L., Baker, H. & Whitehead, S. (2001). ''The UK SPA network: its scope and content''. Joint Nature Conservation Committee, Peterborough.</ref> Some education of mountain-climbers in country holding breeding golden eagles has been undertaken by the [[Mountaineering Council of Scotland]].<ref>Mountaineering Council of Scotland. (2009). ''A brief guide to ‘birds at crags’ from climbers''. With particular reference to peregrine falcons and eagles.</ref> Within the United States, the golden eagle is legally protected by the [[Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act]].<ref name= Ferguson-Lees/> In the United States, many studies of the effects of industrialization and development have been undertaken by the very companies attempting to develop near areas holding golden eagles, in order to understand and hopefully minimize harmful effects. For example, [[Swan Falls Dam|Swan Falls electric power-plant]] in southern Idaho has funded research into the effects of reconstruction activities on breeding raptors (including the golden eagles), the Arch Mineral Corporation has funded studies attempting to test and successfully relocate golden eagle nests and KENETECH Windpower and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory have funded research into the effects of turbine-based wind energy on golden eagles.<ref name= Hunt/><ref>Holthuijzen, A.M.A. (1989). ''Behavior and productivity of nesting Prairie Falcons in relation to construction activities at Swan Falls Dam''. Final Report, Idaho Power Company, Boise, Idaho.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Fala, R.A.|author2= Anderson, A. |author3= Ward, J.P. |year=1985|title=Highwall to pole Golden Eagle nest site relocations|journal= Journal of Raptor Research|volume= 19|pages= 1–7}}</ref> In the 1970s in the United States, bounds were made to reduce the number of golden eagles to die from electrocution and wire-collisions. The primary change has been to raise the central insulator more than {{convert|1|m|ft|abbr=on}} above the cross-arm and to position the ground-wire at a lower height on the pole, both likely to reduce the probability of golden eagles striking the wires with their wings. Also, the power company may place an insulating tube from {{convert|1|to|2|m|ft|abbr=on}} on either side of the pole attachment or, especially if the previous modifications are not feasible, install raised perches at the top of the power pole.<ref>Nelson, M. W. & Nelson, P. (1977). "Power lines and birds of prey", pp. 228–242 in ''World Conference on Birds of Prey: report of proceedings'', Vienna 1975 (R. D. Chancellor, Ed.). International Council for Bird Preservation, London.</ref> In Spain, the issue of electrocutions is more intractable because all pylons were made out of metal, which makes them much more dangerous to wildlife flying into them.<ref>Ferrer, M. (1993). ''El Aquila Imperial''. Quercus, Madrid.</ref>
== Effects on conservation-dependent species == On the conservation front, the golden eagle is unintentionally contributing to the conservation crisis of another animal, the [[island fox]], a small insular relative of the [[gray fox]] found only in the [[Channel Islands of California]]. The island fox had evolved without major natural predators but the large breeding population of golden eagles in [[California]] is feeding partially on the foxes, whose already declining population cannot support sustained predation.<ref>[http://www.iucnredlist.org/apps/redlist/details/22781/0 ''Urocyon littoralis'' (California Channel Island Fox, Channel Islands Fox, Island Fox, Island Gray Fox, Island Grey Fox)]. Iucnredlist.org. Retrieved on 2012–08–22.</ref>
Also in [[North America]], attempts to reintroduce endangered [[whooping crane]]s by mixing them with flocks of sandhill cranes have been largely unsuccessful in part due to natural predators picking off the unnaturally unwary birds. Although the chief predator has been bobcats, golden eagles are one of the other predators that are habitually killing the birds.<ref name="Clegg">{{cite journal |last=Ellis |first=D.H. |first2=K.R. |last2=Clegg |first3=J.C. |last3=Lewis |first4=E. |last4=Spaulding|url=https://sora.unm.edu/node/105543 |title=Golden Eagle predation on experimental Sandhill and Whooping cranes |journal=Condor |volume=101 |issue=3 |pages=664–6 |year=1999 |jstor=1370196 |doi=10.2307/1370196}}</ref>
The golden eagle may be a competitor and, rarely, a predator of the recently reintroduced California condors in central Arizona and southern California, but the pressure exerted by the eagles on condors are seemingly minor, especially in contrast to manmade conservation issues for the species such as lead poisoning from bullets left in hunter-killed ungulate carcasses.<ref name="Snyder">{{cite journal |author1=Snyder, N.F.R. |author2=Ramey, R.R. |author3=Sibley, F.C. |title=Nest-site biology of the California Condor |journal=Condor |volume=88 |issue=2 |pages=228–241 |year=1986 |jstor=1368920 |doi=10.2307/1368920}}</ref><ref name="Meretsky">Meretsky, V.J., Snyder, N.F.R., Beissinger, S.R., Clendenen, D.A. & Wiley, J.W. (2000). "Demography of the California Condor: implications for reestablishment". Conservation Biology NatureServe. 2010. ''NatureServe Explorer: An Online Encyclopedia of Life'' [web application].</ref>
In Scotland, the common hen harrier has been the subject of much unfavorable attention due to the fact that it is a habitual predator of the chicks of red grouse, a subspecies considered to be near threatened in the nation. One of the methods to control harrier numbers has been proposed is to encourage a population increase of golden eagles, which may also hunt grouse but are unlikely to cull young grouse and tend to outcompete and sometimes hunt the harriers themselves.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Thompson, P.S.|author2= Amar, A.|author3= Hoccom, D.G.|author4= Knott, J.|author5= Wilson, J.D. |title=Resolving the conflict between driven-grouse shooting and conservation of Hen Harriers |journal=Journal of Applied Ecology |volume=46 |issue=5 |pages=950–4 |year=2009 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2664.2009.01687.x }}</ref>
==References==
{{reflist}}
[[Category:Eagles|Golden eagle conservation]] [[Category:Bird problems with humans]] [[Category:Bird mortality|Golden eagle]] [[Category:Bird conservation|Golden eagle]]

{{About|the artificial life scientist|the architect, town planner, author and poet|Steen Eiler Rasmussen}} {{for|the Danish Olympic athlete|Steen Rasmussen (athlete)}} {{BLP primary sources|date=June 2010}} '''Steen Rasmussen''' (born 7 July 1955) is a Danish physicist mainly working in the areas of [[artificial life]] and [[complex systems]]. He is currently a professor in physics and a center director at [[University of Southern Denmark]] as well as an external research professor at the [[Santa Fe Institute]]. His formal training was at the [[Technical University of Denmark]] (1985 PhD in physics of complex systems) and [[University of Copenhagen]] (philosophy). He spent 20 years as a researcher at [[Los Alamos National Laboratory]] (1988-2007) the last five years as a leader of the Self-Organized Systems team. He has been part of the [[Santa Fe Institute]] since 1988.
The main scientific effort of Steen Rasmussen over the last ten years has been to explore, understand and construct a transition from nonliving to living materials. Bridging this gap requires an interdisciplinary scientific effort, which is why he has assembled, sponsored and lead research teams in the US, across Europe and in Denmark. He became a scientific team leader in 2002 at Los Alamos National Laboratory, USA, and he has since held research leadership positions at the [[Santa Fe Institute]], [[University of Copenhagen]] and [[University of Southern Denmark]]. Since late 2007 he has been the director of the Center for Fundamental Living Technology at [[University of Southern Denmark]].
Steen Rasmussen has for many years been actively engaged in the public discourse regarding science and society and on this background he founded the Initiative for Science, Society and Policy (ISSP) in 2009. ISSP is currently funded by two Danish universities, has a Director, five Science Focus Leaders and a Science Board.
==External links== * [http://flint.sdu.dk/index.php?page=steen-rasmussen Steen Rasmussen at SDU] * [http://www.santafe.edu/about/people/profile/Steen%20Rasmussen Steen Rasmussen at SFI]
{{Authority control}}

{{Infobox film | name = The Missing | image = Missing ver2.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ron Howard]] | producer = [[Brian Grazer]]
Ron Howard
Daniel Ostroff | writer = Ken Kaufman | based on = {{Based on|''[[The Last Ride (novel)|The Last Ride]]''|[[Thomas Eidson]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Tommy Lee Jones]]|[[Cate Blanchett]]|[[Evan Rachel Wood]]|[[Jenna Boyd]]|[[Aaron Eckhart]]|[[Val Kilmer]]}} | music = [[James Horner]] | cinematography = [[Salvatore Totino]] | editing = {{ubl|[[Daniel P. Hanley]]|[[Mike Hill (film editor)|Mike Hill]]}} | studio = {{ubl|[[Revolution Studios]]|[[Imagine Entertainment]]}} | distributor = [[Columbia Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2003|11|26}} | runtime = 137 minutes{{cite web|title=''THE MISSING'' (15)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/missing-2004-6|work=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=2003-11-10|accessdate=2012-12-22}} | country = United States | language = {{ubl|English|Spanish|Apache}} | budget = $60 million{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2003-11-30/news/0311300411_1_film-western-missing|title=Howard gets his wish: A rough, tough western|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=November 30, 2003|accessdate=November 17, 2015}} | gross = $38.4 million }} '''''The Missing''''' is a 2003 American [[Revisionist Western]] [[thriller film]] directed by [[Ron Howard]], based on [[Thomas Eidson]]'s 1996 novel ''[[The Last Ride (novel)|The Last Ride]]''. The film is set in 1885 [[New Mexico Territory]] and is notable for the authentic use of the [[Southern Athabaskan languages|Apache]] language by various actors, some of whom spent long hours studying it.{{cite web| url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20031218&slug=nativespeakers18| title=Apaches laud accuracy in 'The Missing' movie| author=Richard Benke| date=December 18, 2003| publisher=The Seattle Times| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} The film was produced by [[Revolution Studios]], [[Imagine Entertainment]], and Daniel Ostroff Productions and distributed by [[Columbia Pictures]].{{cite web| url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/286088/The-Missing/credits| title=The Missing (2003)| publisher=New York Times| accessdate=July 25, 2014}}{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0338188/companycredits?ref_=tt_dt_co| title=The Missing (2003)| publisher=IMDB| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} ==Plot== In late 19th-century New Mexico, Samuel Jones reappears hoping to reconcile with his adult daughter Magdalena "Maggie" Gilkeson. She is unable to forgive him for abandoning the family and leaving her mother to a hard life and early death. This situation changes when Pesh-Chidin and a dozen of his followers (who have left the reservation) pass through the area, ritualistically killing settlers and taking their daughters to be sold into sex slavery in Mexico. Among those captured is Maggie's eldest daughter, Lilly. Maggie's rancher boyfriend Brake Baldwin was among the settlers killed. The [[U.S. Cavalry]] refuses to help retrieve the captive women as its resources are tied up conducting forced relocation of captive [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]]. This leaves Maggie, her father, and her younger daughter Dot alone in tracking the attackers. The group unexpectedly meets up with Kayitah, a [[Chiricahua]], and an old friend of Jones, who also happens to be tracking the attackers with his son Honesco, because among the captives is a young Chiricahua woman who is engaged to Honesco. After the two agree to join the group, and Maggie treats Honesco's injuries, Kayitah informs Maggie that Jones had been a member of their Chiricahua band where he gained the name Chaa-duu-ba-its-iidan ("shit for luck") during his wanderings. It is finally with the combined efforts of the two families that they are able to free the women, at the cost of Kayitah's life, and immediately flee to the mountains with the kidnappers behind them. Knowing they have no other choice but to stand their ground, the group fights off the remaining kidnappers. During the battle, Jones fights El Brujo, the one responsible for kidnapping his granddaughter. When Brujo attempts to kill Maggie with a shotgun, Jones sacrifices his life to save his daughter as both he and Brujo fall off a cliff to their deaths. Maggie shoots at the last remaining kidnappers to scare them off. She realizes her father's love for her and finally forgives him. Then she goes home with her father’s body, her daughters and the other kidnapped girls. ==Cast== * [[Tommy Lee Jones]] as Samuel Jones/Chaa-duu-ba-its-iidan * [[Cate Blanchett]] as Magdalena "Maggie" Gilkeson * [[Evan Rachel Wood]] as Lilly Gilkeson * [[Jenna Boyd]] as Dot Gilkeson * [[Aaron Eckhart]] as Brake Baldwin * [[Val Kilmer]] as Lt. Jim Ducharme * [[Sergio Calderón]] as Emiliano * [[Eric Schweig]] as Pesh-Chidin/El Brujo * [[Elisabeth Moss]] as Anne * [[Steve Reevis]] as Two Stone * [[Jay Tavare]] as Kayitah * [[Simon R. Baker]] as Honesco * [[Deryle J. Lujan]] as Naazhaao * [[David Midthunder]] as Happy Jim * [[Clint Howard]] as Sheriff Purdy * [[Ray McKinnon (actor)|Ray McKinnon]] as Russell J. Wittick * [[Max Perlich]] as Issac Edgerly ==Reception== The film earned mixed reviews from critics, earning it a 58% rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] with the general consensus being: "an expertly acted and directed Western. But like other Ron Howard features, the movie is hardly subtle."{{cite web| url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1127407-missing/| title=The Missing (2003)| publisher=Rotten Tomatoes| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} Philip French of ''[[The Observer]]'' referred to the film as Howard’s "finest film to date,"{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/feb/29/philipfrench| title=New lessons from the Old West| author=Phillip French| date=February 28, 2004| publisher=The Observer| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} and Michael Wilmington of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' called it the "best and toughest western since ''[[Unforgiven]]''."{{cite web| url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/movies/mmx-031125-movies-review-mw-themissing,0,4314207.story| title=Movie review: 'The Missing'| author=Michael Wilmington| date=November 24, 2003| publisher=Chicago Tribune| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} ''The Missing'' was well received among Native American populations within the United States, many of which citing the use of the Apache language to be clearly spoken and well understood. Actors such as Tommy Lee Jones, Jay Tavare, Simon R. Baker, and others had to learn to speak the Chiricahua dialect of the Apache language that was used throughout the film.{{cite web| url=http://americanindian.net/reviewsthemissing.html| title=Phil Konstantin's Review of The Missing| author=Phil Konstantin| date=September 2004| publisher=AmericanIndian.net| accessdate=July 25, 2014}} Tavare has noted that there are only about 300 people still fluent in Chiricahua today, and following screenings of the film, Native American students said the film helped stimulate pride through its authenticity. ''The Missing'' grossed $27 million domestically and $11.4 million internationally for a worldwide total of $38.4 million.{{mojo title|missing03|The Missing}} ==References== {{reflist|40em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.sonypictures.com/homevideo/themissing/index.html}} * {{imdb title|0338188|The Missing}} * {{allmovie|286088|The Missing}} * {{mojo title|missing03|The Missing}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|1127407-missing|The Missing}} * {{metacritic film|the-missing|The Missing}} {{Ron Howard}} {{Brian Grazer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Missing, The}} [[Category:2003 films]] [[Category:2000s adventure films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s thriller films]] [[Category:2000s Western (genre) films]] [[Category:American adventure drama films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American thriller films]] [[Category:American Western (genre) films]] [[Category:Columbia Pictures films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films scored by James Horner]] [[Category:Films about abduction]] [[Category:Films about death]] [[Category:Films about families]] [[Category:Films based on American novels]] [[Category:Films based on Western (genre) novels]] [[Category:Films set in New Mexico]] [[Category:Films set in the 1880s]] [[Category:Films shot in New Mexico]] [[Category:Films directed by Ron Howard]] [[Category:Films produced by Brian Grazer]] [[Category:Imagine Entertainment films]] [[Category:Revolution Studios films]] [[Category:Spanish-language films]] [[Category:Apache-language films]]

page.title: The e!DAL Plant Phenomics and Genomics Research Data Repository

revision.text:
The '''Plant Genomics and Phenomics Research Data Repository''' (PGP) is a data publication infrastructure to comprehensively publish multi-domain plant research data<ref name="Arend et al. 2016">{{cite journal|last1=Arend|first1=Daniel|last2=Junker|first2=Astrid|last3=Scholz|first3=Uwe|last4=Schüler|first4=Danuta|last5=Wylie|first5=Juliane|last6=Lange|first6=Matthias|date=16 April 2016|title=PGP repository: a plant phenomics and genomics data publication infrastructure|journal=Database|volume=2016|issue=baw033|pages=baw033|doi=10.1093/database/baw033|pmid=27087305|pmc=4834206|ref=ASS06}}</ref>. It is hosted at the [[Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research]] (IPK) in [[Gatersleben]], Germany. The repository hosts DOI citeable datasets that are not being published in public repositories because of its volume or data scope. PGP enable the publication of gigabyte scale datasets and is registered as research data repository at [[FAIRSharing.org]], [[Registry of Research Data Repositories|re3data.org]] and [[OpenAIRE]] as valid EU Horizon 2020 open data archive. Above features, the programmatic interface and the support of standard metadata formats, enable PGP to fulfil the [[FAIR data]] principles—findable, accessible, interoperable, reusable. The PGP repository was created using the [[e!DAL]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Arend|first=Daniel|last2=Lange|first2=Matthias|last3=Chen|first3=Jinbo|last4=Colmsee|first4=Christian|last5=Flemming|first5=Steffen|last6=Hecht|first6=Denny|last7=Scholz|first7=Uwe|date=2014|title=e!DAL - a framework to store, share and publish research data|journal=BMC Bioinformatics|language=En|volume=15|issue=1|pages=214|doi=10.1186/1471-2105-15-214|issn=1471-2105|pmc=4080583|pmid=24958009}}</ref> software infrastructure and applies the "bring the infrastructure to the data" (I2D) approach.
=== Data Content === All submitted and approved data will be hosted at IPK Gatersleben and is long-term stable citable by an DOI. All datsets are linked in [[ORCID]] and index by all major web search engines. The PGP repository is accepted by data journals like [[GigaScience]] and [[Scientific Data (journal)|Nature Scientific Data]] as recommended data repository. All published datasets may be explored in the PGP data report application or retrieved using the [[DataCite]] search web application.
=== Data Submission === The PGP repository accept submissions from European plant science community. The web based submission tool for small datasets and [[Java_(programming_language)|Java]] desktop submission tool for gigabyte scale datasets use the [[ELIXIR]] Authentication and Authorization Infrastructure (AAI). A review process ensures the technical quality of data submissions.
=== German Network for Bioinformatics Infrastructure (de.NBI) ===
The PGP repository is a part of the service portfolio of the ''German Crop BioGreenformatics Network'' (GCBN) node of the [[German Network for Bioinformatics Infrastructure]].
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://edal-pgp.ipk-gatersleben.de/ official repository website] * [https://edal.ipk-gatersleben.de/ official e!DAL website] * [https://edal.ipk-gatersleben.de/ official website of the Leibniz Institute of Plant Genetics and Crop Plant Research (IPK)]
[[Category:Data]] [[Category:Life sciences]] [[Category:Open data]]

{{Infobox baseball biography |name = Tom Gamboa |image = |image_size = |team = |number = |position = [[Coach (baseball)|Coach]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1948|2|28}} |birth_place = [[Los Angeles, California]] |bats = Left |throws = Left }} '''Thomas Harold Gamboa''' (born February 28, 1948) is the former manager of the [[Brooklyn Cyclones]].
Gamboa has managed in the minor leagues as high as AAA (the [[Toledo Mud Hens]] in the [[International League]] and the [[Albuquerque Dukes]] in the [[Pacific Coast League]]), and coached first and third base as well as in the bullpen for major league teams (the [[Chicago Cubs]] and [[Kansas City Royals]]). In September 2016, Gamboa was the bench coach for [[Israel at the World Baseball Classic#2017 tournament|Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic]] qualifier, and he continued in the same role for [[Israel at the World Baseball Classic#2017 tournament|Team Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic]] main tournament in South Korea and Japan.
==Early and personal life== Gamboa was born in Los Angeles, California, and now lives in [[Rancho Mirage]], California.<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://www.brooklyncyclones.com/teamega/cyclones/coaches/?staff_id=46 Brooklyn Cyclones | MCU Park: Coaches<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was raised by his mother, Polly, and his step-father (whose surname he took), Jack Donald Gamboa.<ref name=autogenerated4>[http://www.greatest21days.com/2014/09/interview-part-1-tom-gamboa.html "Interview Part 1: Tom Gamboa, Accomplished Something"<!-- Bot generated title -->], The Greatest 21 Days</ref><ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/195306512/ July 12, 2007 · Page 17<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''The Desert Sun from Palm Springs, California''</ref> Gamboa is fluent in Spanish.<ref>[https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/99238340/ July 7, 1986 · Page 46<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''Detroit Free Press''</ref> He has five children.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> His son Brett is an assistant professor of English at [[Dartmouth College]].<ref>[https://www.sentinelsource.com/news/local/camino-trail-a-special-pilgrimage-for-local-family/article_4ab83fc2-f85e-528c-81e1-9615d80bb9a6.html]</ref>
He was drafted out of [[Notre Dame High School (Sherman Oaks, California)|Notre Dame High School]] in [[Sherman Oaks]], California, where he was a first baseman, by the Baltimore Orioles, but instead attended the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] (B.A., History, 1971) on a full scholarship.<ref name=autogenerated4 /><ref name=autogenerated7>[http://articles.latimes.com/2002/sep/21/sports/sp-brawlfolo21 "Royal Coach Denies Exchange"<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''Los Angeles Times''</ref><ref>[https://www.scribd.com/doc/59281982/2011-Los-Angeles-Angels-Media-Guide 2011 Los Angeles Angels Media Guide | Home Run<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> There, he played primarily center field, along with a little first base, for the [[UC Santa Barbara Gauchos baseball|Gauchos baseball team]] for three years and won All-[[Big West Conference]] honors in 1969 and 1970.<ref name=autogenerated1>[https://www.baseball-reference.com/register/player.cgi?id=gamboa001tom Tom Gamboa Register Statistics & History<!-- Bot generated title -->], Baseball-Reference.com</ref><ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated6>[http://baseballhistorian.blogspot.com/2015/11/tom-gamboa-baseball-life.html "Tom Gamboa: A Baseball Life"<!-- Bot generated title -->], The Baseball Historian</ref>
==Playing career== During the 1971–1972 seasons Gamboa was an outfielder for and manager of Stratford (Ontario) in the Canadian Baseball League, where he was a two-time All-Star.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==Managing, scouting, and coaching career== ===Minor Leagues=== Gamboa was a manager, minor league instructor, and scouting supervisor in the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] organization from 1978–1982.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> In 1979, at the age of 31, he managed the [[Butte Copper Kings]] in the Rookie [[Pioneer League (baseball)|Pioneer League]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> In 1983 he managed the Paintsville Brewers in the Rookie [[Appalachian League]] to a league-leading .653 won-loss percentage, and the league title.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=autogenerated2 /> In 1984 he managed the [[Beloit Brewers]] in the Class A [[Midwest League]] to a Central Division-leading .619 won-lost percentage, and was voted Manager of the Year.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=autogenerated2 /> In 1985 he managed the [[Stockton Ports]] in the Class A [[California League]] to a North Division-leading .566 won-loss percentage, and the Division championship.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>[http://www.milb.com/content/page.jsp?sid=t524&ymd=20090928&content_id=7204980&vkey=team4 "Alumni Memories" | Stockton Ports Franchise Info<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1986 he managed the [[Bristol Tigers]] in the Appalachian League and served as the [[Detroit Tigers]] western states scouting director, and in 1987 he managed the [[Glens Falls Tigers]] in the AA [[Eastern League (baseball)|Eastern League]]; both, affiliates of the [[Detroit Tigers]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /> He was the minor league field coordinator for the Detroit Tigers from 1987–1990.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> He managed the [[Toledo Mud Hens]] in the AAA [[International League]] for the Detroit Tigers in 1990.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated5>[http://www.thebaseballcube.com/players/profile.asp?P=tom-gamboa&Page=Jobs Tom Gamboa Baseball Statistics<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He was the Director of Minor League Instruction for the [[San Diego Padres]] from 1991-94.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> He was the [[Chicago Cubs]]' Minor League Field Coordinator from 1995–1998.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated5 />
In 2000, he managed the Dodgers' [[Albuquerque Dukes]] of the AAA [[Pacific Coast League]] to a Central Division-leading .597 won-lost percentage and title.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=autogenerated2 />
In 2005, he managed the [[Arkansas Travelers]] of the AA [[Texas League]] to the Texas League Eastern Division title for the Los Angeles Angels.<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=autogenerated2 /> In 2006 and 2007, he was Minor League Outfield/Baserunning Coordinator for the San Diego Padres.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> In 2009, he was the minor league field coordinator for the Padres.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
In 2011, he managed the [[Inland Empire 66ers]] of the Class A+ California League (through June, when he resigned to spend time with his 85-year-old mother, who was terminally ill with advanced cancer), an affiliate of the [[Los Angeles Angels]].<ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref>[http://www.greatest21days.com/2014/09/interview-part-4-tom-gamboa-truly.html "Interview Part 4: Tom Gamboa, Truly Passionate"<!-- Bot generated title -->], The Greatest 21 Days</ref><ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jun/01/sports/la-sp-0602-angels-fyi-20110602 Angels FYI: "Angels' small infielders play big"<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''Los Angeles Times''</ref> That year he also played "Scout Martinez" in the Oscar-nominated 2011 baseball movie ''[[Moneyball (film)|Moneyball]]''.<ref>[http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/37/10/all-new-cyclones-coach-2014-03-07-bk_37_10.html "'Moneyball' star Tom Gamboa becomes new manager of the Brooklyn Cyclones"<!-- Bot generated title -->], ''Brooklyn Paper''</ref>
During the 2012 [[California Winter League (2010)|California Winter League]] (Palm Springs, California), Gamboa served as the Field Coordinator.<ref>[https://powerbaseball.wordpress.com/page/9/?pages-list "Palm Springs POWER: It's a Pleasure Doing Baseball with You" | Baseball in the Desert | Page 9<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
From 2014 to 2016, he managed the [[Brooklyn Cyclones]] of the Short-Season A [[New York-Pennsylvania League]], an affiliate of the [[New York Mets]].<ref name=autogenerated1 />
===Major Leagues=== From 1973-1975 he was a scout for the [[Baltimore Orioles]], and from 1976–1977 he was a scout for the [[Major League Baseball Scouting Bureau]].<ref name=autogenerated2 />
He was the Chicago Cubs' first base and third base coach in 1998–1999.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated5 />
Gamboa was a Major League coach for the [[Kansas City Royals]] from 2001–2003, serving as the bullpen coach in 2001 and 2003 and the team's first base coach in 2002.<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated5 /><ref name=dism>{{cite news|last=Falkoff|first=Robert|title=Royals dismiss Gamboa|url=http://kansascity.royals.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20030929&content_id=550949&vkey=news_kc&fext=.jsp&c_id=kc|accessdate=2012-06-04|newspaper=[[MLB]]|date=2003-09-29}}</ref><ref name=retr>{{cite web|title=Tom Gamboa|url=http://www.retrosheet.org/boxesetc/G/Pgambt801.htm|work=Tom Gamboa|publisher=[[Retrosheet]]|accessdate=2012-06-04}}</ref> While he was the Royals first base coach, he was attacked on the field at [[U.S. Cellular Field|Comiskey Park]] by two fans during a game against the [[Chicago White Sox]] on September 19, 2002. Gamboa suffered permanent [[hearing loss]] in his right ear.<ref name=ligu>{{cite web|title=Royals vs. The Ligues September 19, 2002|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/multimedia/photo_gallery/1010/player-fan.altercations/content.10.html|work=Player-Fan Altercations|publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]]|accessdate=2012-06-04}}</ref><ref>[http://www.greatest21days.com/2014/09/interview-part-3-tom-gamboa-strange-deal.html Interview Part 3: Tom Gamboa, Strange Deal<!-- Bot generated title -->], The Greatest 21 Days</ref>
===International winter leagues===
Gamboa managed the [[Indios de Mayagüez]] in Puerto Rico's [[Liga de Béisbol Profesional Roberto Clemente]] in seven winter league seasons from 1995–96 through 2002–03, reaching the finals in six seasons and winning three championships, managed in six Puerto Rican League All-Star games, and was named Manager of the Year following the 1995–96 and 1996-97 seasons.<ref name=autogenerated2 /> In 2002, he was inducted into the Association of Major League Legends of Latin America.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
Gamboa managed [[Naranjeros de Hermosillo]] in the [[Liga Mexicana del Pacífico]] winter league in 2004.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
===Team Israel; World Baseball Classic=== In September 2016, Gamboa was the bench coach for [[Israel at the World Baseball Classic#2017 tournament|Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic]] qualifier.<ref name=autogenerated3>[https://brooklynbaseballbanter.com/2016/11/30/tom-gamboa-to-remain-israeli-bench-coach/ "Tom Gamboa To Remain Israeli Bench Coach"<!-- Bot generated title -->], Brooklyn Baseball Banter</ref> In an interview, he said he was serving as a Coach, due to his longtime friendship with Manager [[Jerry Weinstein]], and his knowledge of MCU Park (where the Qualifier was being played) even though he wasn't Jewish. He continued in a similar role for [[Israel at the World Baseball Classic#2017 tournament|Team Israel at the 2017 World Baseball Classic]] main tournament in South Korea and Japan. During those games, Gamboa served as 3B coach as well.<ref name=autogenerated3 />
===College league===
In 2010, he managed the Palm Springs Power of the Southern California Collegiate Baseball League to a 34-4 mark, the best in team history.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
==Book== In 2018, he and David Russell co-wrote the autobiography ''Tom Gamboa: My Life In Baseball'' (McFarland), which sports columnist [[Mike Vaccaro]] of ''[[The New York Post]]'' described as "a fun read," and Lloyd Carroll of ''NY Sports Day'' described as "a fascinating look at a baseball professional who has spent as most of his life beating the bushes of baseball’s minor leagues."<ref>[https://www.nysportsday.com/2018/01/06/the-week-that-was-the-isles-are-as-cold-as-the-thermometer/ The Week That Was: The Isles Are As Cold As The Thermometer – NY Sports Day<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[https://nypost.com/2018/01/20/every-new-york-fan-base-has-felt-saints-supporters-pain/ Every New York fan base has felt Saints supporters’ pain<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated8>[http://www.qgazette.com/news/2018-01-17/Features/Forest_Hills_Native_CoAuthors_Autobio_On_Baseball_.html Forest Hills Native Co-Authors Autobio On Baseball Veteran | www.qgazette.com | Queens Gazette<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[https://player.fm/series/beyond-the-game-1337340/tom-gamboa-interview-new-york-basketball-and-mlb-and-nfl-news-1-23-18 Tom Gamboa Interview, New York Basketball, And MLB And NFL News 1-23-18 - Beyond The Game (podcast)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The book’s forward is written by baseball player [[Doug Glanville]].<ref name=autogenerated8 />
==Minor league managing career== {{Div col}} * Paintsville Brewers (1983) * [[Beloit Brewers]] (1984) * [[Stockton Ports]] (1985) * [[Bristol Tigers]] (1986) * [[Albuquerque Dukes]] (2000)<ref name=dod>{{cite news|title=Baseball Dodgers: Named Tom Gamboa manager and Ron Jackson hitting coach|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1999-12-18/sports/9912180139_1_men-s-soccer-coach-beckett-hollenbach-all-south-atlantic|accessdate=2012-06-04|newspaper=[[Baltimore Sun]]|date=1999-12-18}}</ref> * [[Arkansas Travelers]] (2005) * Palm Springs Power (2010) * [[Inland Empire 66ers]] (2011) first half * [[Brooklyn Cyclones]] (2014–2016)<ref name=sri>{{cite news|title=Tom Gamboa talks about fans taking the field|url=http://espn.go.com/espn/page2/index?id=5165556|accessdate=2012-06-04|publisher=[[ESPN]] Page 2|date=2010-05-04}}</ref> {{Div col end}}
